---
title: Use of management strategy evaluation to inform in fisheries management in a changing climate
---

# Introduction
For most of its history fisheries management has prodominately focused on fishing impacts with ecosystem status viewed as a background constant. The increasing rate and degree of ecosystem climatic change is changing this dynamic, bringing ecosystem status to the forefront of fisheries management.

Management strategy evaluation (MSE) is commonly considered the gold standard of fisheries management approaches, and is "widely considered to be the most appropriate way to evaluate the trade‐offs achieved by alternative management strategies and to assess the consequences of uncertainty for achieving management goals” (citation). Thus, MSE is a compelling tool to address the impact of climate change on fisheries management.

Despite numerous applications of MSE, the applications that include climate change are limited, leaving uncertainty about the best approach to MSE use for fisheries management that accounts for a changing environment.

Adaptive management arose to address uncertainties and accelerate progress towards meeting management objectives. Using the structured decision making (SDM) process- the decision making framework in which adaptive management occurs - as our framework, how do published MSE projects utilize standard SDM components?  

```{r, include=FALSE}
knitr::write_bib(c('posterdown', 'rmarkdown','pagedown'), 'packages.bib')
```

## Objectives
We review published management strategy evaluations (MSEs) against the steps of a structured decision making (SDM) framework to note how the literature accelerates or delays learning. 

* Identify explicit documentation and use (or disuse) of SDM steps in MSEs that enable or limit adaptation in future MSEs.
* Identify participants in MSE processes that enable or limit adaptation in future MSEs.
* Highlight unique aspects of MSEs that model climate change as a driver
* Identify aspects of successful MSEs that can be adopted to inform fisheries management in a changing climate  
* Provide insights about MSE processes and documentation that can further learning to improve future MSEs

# Methods
#### Published MSE article selection
We conducted our search for management strategy evaluations (MSEs) in the SCI-EXPANDED index from Web of Science, searching for “management strategy evaluation” by topic across all years on January 8th, 2019. This search returned 253 results.  

We took a random sample of these 253 articles and reviewed 30 that document a management strategy evaluation.  Not all articles in the potential pool of 253 articles were management strategy evaluations due to articles that are reviews, meta-analyses, etc., or simply cite other MSE articles.  Of the 253 articles ### documented a management strategy evaluation, and 11 included climate change as a driver of fishery status.

| MSE type | Count |
|:--:|:--:|
| Published | ### |
| Reviewed Sample | 30 |
| Climate Change | 11 |

We highlight lessons learned from these exercises and unique aspects of MSEs that model climate change as a driver relative to a sample of MSEs that do not consider climate change.
